facts.text: Forty persons were charged with several offences, principal one under section 302 read with S. 149 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Forty person were charged with having companymitted several offences the principal one of which was under section 302 read with S. 149 of the Indian Penal Code. The case against these persons was tried by the first Additional Sessions judge at Jhansi.

facts.text: The case was tried by the first Additional Sessions Judge at Jhansi.

anchor.surface_text: The case against these persons was tried by the first Additional Sessions judge at Jhansi. The other charges framed against them were under s. 307 149, 201/ 149 SI 1, 395, 396, 149 449, 1. P. C.

facts.text: The trial Judge held that a number of charges had been proved against five of the accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge held that numbere of the char-es had been proved against five of the accused persons. .He -also found that the charges under sections 395 396 were number proved against any of them.

facts.text: 35 out of 40 accused persons were found guilty by the trial Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the remaining charges. he found that 35 out of 40 accused persons were guilty. For the major offence charged under s. 302/149, he sentenced 10 accused persons to death and 25 others to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Trial Judge sentenced 10 accused to death and 25 to life imprisonment for s.302/149.

anchor.surface_text: For the major offence charged under s. 302/149, he sentenced 10 accused persons to death and 25 others to imprisonment for life. He also directed that the said accused persons should undergo different terms of imprisonment for the remaining offences

facts.text: Trial Judge pronounced judgment on 31st December 1962.

anchor.surface_text: After the learned trial Judge pronounced his judgment on the 31st December 1962, the 35 accused persons who had been companyvicted by him preferred three appeals

facts.text: 35 convicted accused preferred three appeals to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the 35 accused persons who had been companyvicted by him preferred three appeals between them before the Allababad High Court, whereas the sentences of death imposed on 10 accused persons

facts.text: Allahabad High Court judgment dated October 22, 1963 acquitted 7 out of 35 appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has held that 7 out of the 35 appellants before it were number proved to have companymitted any of the offences, and so, they were ordered to be acquitted.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction and sentence for 28 appellants.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the remaining 28 appellants, the High Court has companyfirmed the orders of companyviction and sentence imposed on them by the trial Court.

facts.text: Incident took place on 29th November 1961 at about 8 a.m. in village Bilati Khet, district Jhansi.

anchor.surface_text: The incident which has given rise to the present criminal proceedings took place on the 29th November, 1961 in village Bilati Khet in the district of Jhansi at about 8 a.m.

facts.text: Village Bilati Khet cursed with keen rivalry between two factions: one led by Gayadin, other by Laxmi Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that this village is cursed with keen rivalry and enmity between two factionsOne group was led by Gayadin who and four other members of his family were murdered on the said date.

facts.text: Gayadin and four family members murdered on 29 Nov 1961 by rival faction including appellants.

anchor.surface_text: All these murders were companymitted, according to the prosecution, by the members of the rival faction amongst whom are included the present appellants before us.

facts.text: Laxmi Prasad alias Laxmi Narain is one of the appellants and leader of rival group.

anchor.surface_text: The rival group was led by Laxmi Prasad alias Laxmi Narain who is one of the appellants in this Court. In the last election of the village Panchayat Laxmi Prasad succeeded as Pradhan

facts.text: On 28th November 1961, boundary dispute between groups of Gayadin and Laxmi Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th November, 1961, a boundary dispute led to an incident between the members of the two groups. This dispute related to two fields one of which belonged to Gayadin

facts.text: On 29th November early morning, Bahoran (son of Gayadin) attacked by Laxmi Prasad with lathi, retaliated with pharsa injuring Laxmi Prasad's nose.

anchor.surface_text: On the 29th November in the early morning, Bahoran, one of the sons of Gayadin, had gone out to ease himself. He was then carrying a pharsa. In the field he met Laxmi Prasad who attacked him with a lathi. Bahoran retaliated this attack with his own pharsa and in the scuffle the numbere of Laxmi Prasad was injured

facts.text: Laxmi Prasad collected crowd of his faction after injury.

anchor.surface_text: Infuriated by this injury, Laxmi Prasad went to his house and companylected the whole crowd belonging to his faction.

facts.text: Assailants informed that Laxmi Prasad and companions armed and proceeding to Gayadin's house to kill family.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad and Dayaram rushed to the scene and informed them that Laxmi Prasad and his companypanions were all armed with guns, spears, swords, gandasas and lathis and were proceeding to the house of Gayadin determined to kill all the members of Gayadins family.

facts.text: Laxmi Prasad fired a gun near Gayadin's house; Bhagwati instigated to fire at everyone.

anchor.surface_text: About that time, Laxmi Prasad and his companypanions reached near the house of Gayadin whereon Laxmi Prasad fired a gun. Bhagwati was carrying a large quantity of cartridges in the folds of his dhoti and was instigating Laxmi Prasad to fire at everyone sitting near the fire

facts.text: Assailants broke open doors, entered house, pursued and killed Gayadin on upper storey.

anchor.surface_text: The assailants then broke open the doors of the house and entered the sehan of Gayadin. Inside the house the assailants pursued Gayadin on the upper storey and killed him there.

facts.text: Brindaban, Radha Saran and Dayaram shot dead in different rooms.

anchor.surface_text: Brindaban, Radha Saran and Dayaram were hiding in different rooms of the house the doors of these rooms were broken open and all the three of them were shot dead.

facts.text: Bahoran and Shiroman escaped through roof to Harbans' cattleshed; Shiroman later killed there.

anchor.surface_text: Bahoran and Shiroman Singh, both sons of Gayadin, escaped through the tiled roof into the cattleshed of Harbans which is situated towards the south-east of Gayadins house. Shiroman companycealed himself in the godown while Bahoran companycealed himself in the room

facts.text: Bodies dragged out, Gori Dulaiya (wife of Gayadin) struck with stick when imploring.

anchor.surface_text: After killing Gayadin, Brindaban, Radha Saran and Dayaram, the assailants mercilessly dragged the bodies of the victims out of the house of Gayadin and began their search for Bahoran and other male inmates of the house. When the dead bodies were thus being dragged, Gori Dulaiya wife of Gayadin rushed after the assailants

facts.text: Bodies taken to Harbans' cattleshed, Harbans injured, Shiroman killed.

anchor.surface_text: On reaching the cattleshed of Harbans, the assailants broke open the outer door of the house and entered into it. They then injured Harbans and managed to discover Shiroman Singh who was promptly killed.

facts.text: Five dead bodies placed on piles of dung cakes in Bhagwati's field, set on fire with kerosene.

anchor.surface_text: The five dead bodies were then taken into the field of Bhagwati. In the field two big piles of companydung cakes were prepared. On one of the piles the bodies of Gayadin, Brindaban, Radha Saran and Davaram were placed and on the other Shiroman Singhs body was put. Kerosene oil was sprinkled on the bodies and fire was set to them.

facts.text: Bahoran lodged First Information Report at Police Station Krichh at about 11 o'clock naming 35 assailants.

anchor.surface_text: When the assailants had left the house of Gayadin dragging the dead bodies with them. Rahoran came out of hi,, hiding place and rushed to the Police Station Krichh and lodged the First Information Report at about 11 oclock. In this report,he gave all the material details

facts.text: Police extinguished fire, took half-burnt bodies for post-mortem.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving the first information report, the police party rushed to the scene of occurrence on cycles and they put off the burning fire and took out the half burnt bodies of the five murdered persons.

facts.text: Committal order on 31st March 1962 referred to 35 assailants; five more added on 14th May 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, the first companymittal order passed on the 31st March,1962 in the present proceedings referred to 35 assailants. Later. five more persons were added to the list of assailants by the companymittal order made on the 14th May, 1962.

facts.text: Prosecution case based on 12 eye-witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution is sought to be established by the testimony of 12 eye-witnesses.

facts.text: Present appeals by 16 accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decision of the High Court that the present five appeals have been brought to this Court by special leave, and the number of accused persons who have brought these appeals before us is 16.

facts.text: Supreme Court modifies death sentences to life for accused Nos. 9 Ram Saran (18), 11 Asha Ram (23), 16 Deo Prasad (24).

anchor.surface_text: There are, however, three cases in which we think we ought to interfere. These are the, case of accused No. 9 Ram Saran who is aged 18 accused No. II Asha Ram who is aged 23 and accused No. 16 Deo prasad who is aged 24

anchor.surface_text: Whether or not sentences of death should be imposed on persons who are found to be guilty not because they themselves committed the murder, but because they were members of an unlawful assembly

concepts.interpretation: Death sentence justifiable for armed members of unlawful assembly with common object to exterminate, even if not actual shooters

issues.text: Whether the High Court failed in discharging its duty under s.374 CrPC to independently consider the entire case before confirming death sentences

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals, Mr. Sawhney who has addressed the principal argument before us on behalf of the appellants, has urged that the High Court has failed in discharging its duty properly when it dealt with the appeals brought before it by the appellants and decided to confirm the sentences of death imposed on 10 of the accused persons. In support of this argument, Mr. Sawhney has relied upon the decision of this Court in the case of Jumman Ors. v. The State of Punjab. In that case, this Court has emphasised the fact that the mandatory requirement prescribed by s.374 of the Code of Criminal Procedure shows that in dealing with reference for confirmation of death sentence imposed by the Sessions Judge, the High Court has to consider the entire case for itself before deciding whether the sentence of death

issues.text: Whether failure to examine three material witnesses (Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram, Rani Dulhan) vitiates the trial

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, Mr. Sawhney strongly relied on the fact that the High Court has not considered one important point in favour of the defence, and that is in to the failure of the prosecution to tender three material witnesses whose names had been shown in the witness-list in the calendar sent by the committing Magistrate to the trial Judge. These witnesses are Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram and Rani Dulhan. It appears that this contention was raised by the defence before the Trial Court and had been rejected by it. The Government counsel appearing for the prosecution had made an application to the trial Court expressing his inability to examine the three witnesses for the reason that Ram Prasad and Mansa Ram had been won over by the defence and Rani Dulhan, the widow of one of the victims, was suffering from such mental shock that she was unable to depose coherently.

issues.text: Whether evidence of partisan or interested witnesses should be discarded merely on ground of partisanship

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney has then argued that where witnesses giving evidence in a murder trial like the present are shown to belong to the faction of victims, their evidence should not be accepted, because they are prone to involve falsely mem- bers of the rival faction out of enmity and partisan feeling. There is no doubt that when a criminal Court has to appreciate evidence given by witnesses who are partisan or interested, it has to be very careful in weighing such evidence. Whether or not there are discrepancies in the evidence whether or not the evidence strikes the Court as genuine whether or not the story disclosed by the evidence is prob- able, are all matters which must be taken into account.

issues.text: Whether uniform evidence without assigning specific overt acts to individual assailants is unreliable

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the evidence given by the witnesses conforms to the same uniform pattern and since no specific part is assigned to all the assailants, that evidence should not have been accepted. This criticism again is not well- founded. Where a crowd of assailants who are members of an unlawful assembly proceeds to commit an offence of murder in pursuance of the common object of the unlawful assembly, it is often not possible for witnesses to describe accurately the part played by each one of the assailants.

issues.text: Whether the High Court's test requiring at least four consistent witnesses is mechanical and improper

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney also urged that the test applied by the High Court in convicting the appellants is mechanical. He argues that under the Indian Evidence Act, trustworthy evidence given by a single witness would be enough to convict an accused person, whereas evidence given by half a dozen witnesses which is not trustworthy would not be enough to sustain the conviction. That, no doubt is true but where a criminal court has to deal with evidence pertaining to the commission of an offence involving a large number of offenders and a large number of victims, it is usual to adopt the test that the conviction could be sustained only if it is supported by two or three or more witnesses who give a consistent account of the incident.

issues.text: Whether mere presence in assembly makes one member of unlawful assembly absent overt acts, per Baladin

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney then attempted to argue that the High Court failed to give effect to the principles enunciated by this Court in the case of Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh. In that case, it was observed by Sinha, J., who spoke for the Court, that it is well-settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make a person, who is present, a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under s.142, I.P.C. The argument is that evidence adduced by the prosecution in the present case does not assign any specific part to most of the accused persons in relation to any overt act, and so, the High Court was in error in holding that the appellants were members of an unlawful assembly.

issues.text: The crucial question: whether the assembly consisted of five or more persons entertaining common object under s.141 IPC

anchor.surface_text: What has to be proved against a person who is alleged to be a member of an unlawful assembly is that he was one of the persons constituting the assembly ,and he entertained along with the other members of the assembly the common object as defined by s.141, I.P.C. Section 142 provides that whoever, being aware of facts which render any assembly an unlawful assembly, intentionally joins that assembly, or continues in it, is said to be a member of an unlawful assembly. In other words, an assembly of five or more persons actuated by, and entertaining one or more of the common objects specified by the five clauses of s. 141, is an unlawful assembly. The crucial question to determine in such a case is whether the assembly consisted of five or more persons and whether the said persons entertained one or more of the common objects as specified by s141.

issues.text: Whether death sentences should be imposed on members of unlawful assembly who did not themselves commit the murders but carried firearms

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the judgment delivered by the High Court in these appeals and we are satisfied that the criticism made by Mr. Sawhney that the High Court did not bestow due care and attention on the points involved in the case, cannot be regarded as well- founded

holdings.text: The High Court properly discharged its duty under s.374 CrPC by independently considering the entire case before confirming the death sentences.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the judgment delivered by the High Court in these appeals and we are satisfied that the criticism made by Mr. Sawhney that the High Court did not bestow due care and attention on the points involved in the case, cannot be regarded as well-founded, The judgment shows that the arguments which were urged on behalf of the appellants, have been carefully examined, the evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court judgment demonstrates careful examination of arguments, summarization of evidence, scrutiny of infirmities, consideration of enmity, and application of safe test of four consistent witnesses.

holdings.text: Failure to examine three material witnesses (Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram, Rani Dulhan) does not vitiate the trial.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are not prepared to allow Mr. Sawhney to take us through the evidence in the case on the ground that one important contention raised by the defence has not been examined by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecutor bona fide believed witnesses won over or incapacitated; defence could examine them; court declined s.540 after review finding evidence not essential; point not raised in High Court.

holdings.text: Evidence of partisan or interested witnesses cannot be discarded merely on the ground of partisanship.

anchor.surface_text: But it would, we think, be unreasonable to contend that evidence given by witnesses should be discarded only on the ground that it is evidence of partisan or interested witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts must scrutinize for discrepancies, genuineness, probability; mechanical rejection leads to failure of justice in factional cases.

holdings.text: Uniform evidence without assigning specific overt acts to individual assailants is reliable in cases of large unlawful assemblies committing murder in prosecution of common object.

anchor.surface_text: This criticism again is not well-founded. Where a crowd of assailants who are members of an unlawful assembly proceeds to commit an offence of murder in pursuance of the common object of the unlawful assembly, it is often not possible for witnesses to describe accurately the part played by each one of the assailants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In crowd assaults, not all need participate directly; sufficient arms used for killings.

holdings.text: The High Court's test requiring at least four consistent witnesses is rational and not mechanical in large-scale offences involving many offenders and victims.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do not think that any grievance can be made by the appellants against the adoption of this test. If at all the prosecution may be entitled to say that the seven accused persons were acquitted because their cases did not satisfy the mechanical test of four witnesses,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quality matters but numerical consistency useful safeguard in complex cases; single witness can suffice generally but multiplicity rational here.

holdings.text: Mere presence does not make one a member of unlawful assembly, but appellants were members as they intentionally joined armed assembly with knowledge of common object to exterminate victims' family.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Baladin (passive witnesses context); applies ss.141,142,149: intentional membership with awareness; facts show armed faction assembled for extermination.

holdings.text: To be member of unlawful assembly, one must intentionally join/continue in assembly of 5+ persons with awareness of facts rendering it unlawful and share common object under s.141 IPC; no general overt act required.

anchor.surface_text: What has to be proved against a person who is alleged to be a member of an unlawful assembly is that he was one of the persons constituting the assembly ,and he entertained along with the other members of the assembly the common object as defined by s.141, I.P.C.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of ss.141,142,149; vicarious liability without personal act.

holdings.text: Death sentences under s.302/149 justifiable for armed members of unlawful assembly (firearms carriers) with common object of extermination, even if not actual shooters, based on facts; discretion properly exercised by lower courts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Case-specific: armed group, pre/post conduct, need to suppress; not mechanical but firearms role significant.

holdings.text: Death sentences modified to life imprisonment for accused Nos. 9 (Ram Saran, 18), 11 (Asha Ram, 23), 16 (Deo Prasad, 24) due to youth and likely elder influence.

anchor.surface_text: There are, however, three cases in which we think we ought to interfere. These are the, case of accused No. 9 Ram Saran who is aged 18 accused No. II Asha Ram who is aged 23 and accused No. 16 Deo prasad who is aged 24

holdings.reasoning_summary: Young men compelled by family elders; ends of justice met by life terms.

holdings.text: Convictions and sentences confirmed for all other appellants under s.302/149 IPC and related offences.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence sufficient per lower courts' findings upheld after review.

precedents.citation: Jumman Ors. v. The State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Jumman Ors. v. The State of Punjab

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court must independently consider the entire case and evidence in reference for confirmation of death sentence under s.374 CrPC without being influenced by trial court conclusions
precedents.cited_holding: the mandatory requirement prescribed by s.374 of the Code of Criminal Procedure shows that in dealing with reference for confirmation of death sentence imposed by the Sessions Judge, the High Court has to consider the entire case for itself

precedents.citation: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh

precedents.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: mere presence in an assembly does not make a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless shown that he did something or omitted something making him a member or falls under s.142 IPC
precedents.cited_holding: it is well-settled that mere presence in an assembly does not make a person, who is present, a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under s.142, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Baladin

precedents.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: presence in assembly of family members and villagers where some shared common object and others passive does not necessarily make all members of unlawful assembly

anchor.surface_text: Baladin l

precedents.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: observations must be read in context of special facts and not as unqualified general proposition requiring overt act for membership of unlawful assembly

anchor.surface_text: Baladin 1

precedents.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: principles that appellants are guilty under s.302/149 supported despite Baladin

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab

precedents.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: power to enhance sentence to death should be exercised very rarely and only for strongest reasons; appellate court interferes only if trial discretion improperly exercised
precedents.cited_holding: the power to enhance a sentence from transportation to death should very rarely be exercised and only for the strongest reasons and it was added that it is not enough for the appellate court to say or think that if left to itself it would have awarded the greater penalty

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we confirm the orders of conviction and sentence passed against all the appellants except accused Nos. 9, 11 and 16 in whose cases the sentences are altered to those of imprisonment for life.

outcome.relief_summary: Convictions and sentences confirmed for all appellants except accused Nos. 9 (Ram Saran), 11 (Asha Ram), and 16 (Deo Prasad), whose death sentences modified to life imprisonment.
directions: Sentences of death imposed on accused Nos. 9, 11 and 16 are altered to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: We have carefully considered the judgment delivered by the High Court in these appeals and we are satisfied that the criticism made by Mr. Sawhney that the High Court did not bestow due care and attention on the points involved in the case, cannot be regarded as well-founded, The judgment shows that the arguments which were urged on behalf of the appellants, have been carefully examined, the evidence
